review_title: Do you love doing work and not getting paid for it?
job_title: Senior Academic Advisor in Columbus, OH
pros: Great work/life balance *in most departments.* Decent benefits/good time off policies.
cons: Staff at this university are treated like chattel. They are expected to be highly educated, experienced, flexible, and resilient, but do not see the compensation that folks outside the university do. You have to pay to park on campus (between 50-100/month-probably more now). The campus is very siloed by college and expectations for staff vary by college and even by department within colleges. No matter how many hats you wear or how much you take on, you will never get "promoted" or get a pay increase above 3-4% per year (don't let anyone on this campus try to tell you there's an advising career ladder, it doesn't exist). Anything and everything gets dumped onto academic staff, especially advising staff. The university and the colleges are constantly asking for employee and student feedback and doing nothing with it. The university states that it values diversity, but does the bare minimum to support diverse faculty, staff, and students. HR doesn't value talent, nor do they care to retain the folks that do great work.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: OSU provides all the normal things you can come to expect at a large research institution. Due to its size, nearly everything and anything an individual could want to do or be a part of is available. As a 50% GRA, your entire tuition is covered including various fees. You are a public employee and can contribute to the Ohio Public Employee Retirement System, but have the ability to opt-out if you would like. There's also a form of healthcare, that I do not personally use nor remember many details of but do remember that there is a subsidy paid by OSU to make it more affordable.
cons: The pay as a GRA is capped by the university across all departments and disciplines. Unfortunately, this amount of money typically means that one has to hold a second job off campus to live a stable life.

pros: The flexibility was really nice to have, being able to prioritize classes and not worry about losing my job was reassuring.
cons: My location was often understaffed which made it impossible to be fired as they were so desperate for student workers. The turnover rate was quite high, in the four years I worked here, only one other human had worked there as long as I had. The administrative staff was always changing and people were constantly frustrated with the lack of resources such a large university was unwilling to provide. They refused to hire enough full time employees and during my time there, people often had to work late in order to fulfill orders for the cafe locations. Despite relying on students, they could not reliably take the bus to my location and either had to pay for an expensive parking pass to park in their one lot or hope that the bus was running and if it was running, they would have to spend an extended time waiting for the bus and then waiting on the bus for it to finally make it back to campus. I loved this job, but it was sad to see how little the school prioritized making sure its production kitchen for the entire university was running the best it could.

There are so many layers of HR to get through it takes on average two months to even start a new job. Plus they implemented “career roadmap” which was supposed to improve salaries so we would be more competitive with other institutions. Now every new admin assistant or executive assistant who is hired has a lower salary than the previous posting. Senior leaders were so happy when most of the support staff was switched to salary because now they can email, text or call you 24/7 - because they believe since we are salary we should be available around the clock. I’ve been here 20 years and have heard of horror stories from many staff members who report their managers. In all my time here. I’ve seen one manager fired. pros: Traditional with the RA job, housing comes free. OSU provides a discount on your selected meal plan at around 35%. Every year, RA's have the opportunity to apply to switch to another building/complex on campus – a process made easier if you get to know the Hall Director in the complex you are hoping to move to. RA's also receive a "stipend" of less than $100 per week. Being an RA looks good on a resume and you will recieve a lot of training on diversity and other topics that employers will appreciate. You will also deal with potentially intense situations that make for great lessons learned for a young person. About 90% of the time recruiters know of and respect the role. The other 10% of recruiters may have partied a little in school and will immediately perceive you as a narc, or tattletale, that is uptight and can't have fun. You won't know which type you are talking to until you've presented the fact that you are an RA, and in at least one intance, I think that being an RA severaly damaged a relationship with a professional connection that could have turned into an internship and possibly a full-time offer. This will be the case everywhere with this role – not everyone has fond memories of/with their college RA's! Be an RA that they will remember fondly, though, and you can have a hand in shaping that perception for the future generations.
cons: Ohio State RA's who work another campus job will be disappointed to find out that their hours may be limited in their other role. There are two reasons for this. (1) University HR dictates that students can only work 28 hours/week at maximum, and (2) the Office of Residence Life – under which RA's are technically hired – believes that the RA role may take as much as 20 hours of time per week. The HR restriction is based on what I believe is state law – working more than 28 hours per week, at least at Ohio State, incurrs a requirement that the employer must provide full benefits to the employee. The 20 hours/week rule set by Residence Life is truly ridiculous, and would be the easiest for OSU to solve. No RA is ever putting in 20 hour weeks. If you were to include the hours spent on "on call" shifts (which technically run 12 hours, from 7p to 7a), then you could easily approach this hour count – two shifts scheduled in a week would put you there – but in reality, time actively spent on rounds and supporting residents – assuming you are doing your job as an RA PERFECTLY, being a dream staff member – couldn't possibly pass the five or six hour mark per week. Residence Life calls your weekly pay (a figure under $100/week, as mentioned above) a stipend, but has sollaborated to HR to make sure you are actually being paid hourly – you MUST log 20 hours/week to receive your "stipend," which, at the hourly rate, breaks out to less than $5 per hour. The tragic thing about this is that most students applying to be RA's are enticed by the free housing. Generally, RA's at any school come from low income (or low/no financial support from family) backgrounds, and DO have at least one other campus job – and of course, the minumum wage is far above $5 an hour – the hourly "stipend" rate mentioned above. Not to mention that most other jobs on campus are Federal Work Study roles with a standard pay rate of $10/hour. Over my several years as an RA I will have missed out on several thousand dollars that I could have made – and could easily have worked in addition to my classes and RA role – because of the silly 20 hour/week rule set by Residence Life. The only time I ever called OSU HR to seek a solution to this issue, I was told by a particularly rude representative that they would "never understand kids like me," because we "want to work all through college and miss out on the college experience that will ultiamtely shape our futures." The message was that I am working too hard and needed to take time to enjoy myself – and it was communicated in an attitude that was belittling, by an older adult who clearly still perceived me to be a child confused about their priorities. It upset them greatly when I informed them that I had a third, off-campus job. To a significant population of hard working students at this school, a true 28 hour work week would be doable. The RA required hour count needs to be dropped to 5 or 10 hours/week. Don't get me wrong... As the title suggests, the benefits of this role outweigh the costs... free housing is worth thousands, and a discount on food and access to university dining facilities as an upperclassman is a huge time savings – but prepare to be a little strapped for cash if you have been working another university role and are preparing to become an RA at OSU.

cons:
Fickle, ever-changing leadership goals and priorities. It's like whip lash depending on the day.
Zero administrative support.
New HR tool called WorkDay has made things even worse. With the implementation of WorkDay January 2021, the university came to a screeching halt. No one knows how to operate it. It is one size fits all and not at all an appropriate tool for a university. It has taken months to pay invoices to international partners on sponsored projects. WorkDay also contributes to the already impersonal and alienating nature of day to day life at OSU.

review_title: Not a good place to build a career

job_title: Preschool Assistant Teacher in Columbus, OH
pros:
- Benefits are fantastic (3 weeks paid sick time, 2 weeks vacation time)
- Pay is decent for a child care program 
- Child care program is based on educational/developmental research
- NAEYC Accredited 
- Some managers care about you as a person, some don't (mine did, let me take off work when I needed a mental health day as long as I let her know a day or two ahead of time)
- Never have to take work home (naptime is great for getting stuff done, sometimes) 
- Work/life balance is good
cons:
- Wage equity is BAD right now. I make $1/hr less than someone who has an associate's degree (I have a bachelor's) and 2 years less experience than me. 
- Raises work the same as the rest of OSU. It's barely enough to cover inflation, let alone give you an actual merit-based raise for being a good employee
- There are people working there for the past 10 years who barely make $17/hr. That's ridiculous.

review_title: Benefits Are Good, Culture of "Just Okay"
pros: Health/Dental/Optical benefits are good. If you need to take time off to handle medical visits or family issues, it is acceptable.
cons:
The power structure is not set up to do great work. It is set up to just do "okay" and get through another day. Mostly, this is because there is a contingent of the population who believe they can never get fired for anything. They are typically proven correct and their work is shifted to everyone else.

The compensation is nowhere near the corporate world but that is to be expected in a state job.

There is an undercurrent of racism at all levels. Because it is a university, most employed seem to view themselves as holding liberal values. But essentially it is like having conversations with the characters in Get Out ("I would have voted for Obama 3 times!"). 

They don't see that their refusal to actively cultivate/hire/promote people of color in meaningful roles is perpetuating the same racism they claim to disavow. The culture needs serious work.

review_title: Avoid at all costs, this place will eat your soul
pros:
Easy to get time off.

No culture of micromanagement.

Good team aspect.
cons:
Promotion from within is non existant, expect to see management positions filled with friends and ex coworkers of existing managers that are outside hires.

Annual raises are pathetic, less than 3% while directors and above get large annual bonuses to skirt around that rule.

Money is extremely tight, expect to get pushback even for the most minor of work expenses.

Culture is extremely toxic, you see many instances of employees treating coworkers with ridiculous amounts of disrespect with no correction from management.

Poor employees are allowed to continue with bad habits, management does not take the time to correct employee behavior. From inappropriateness to outright terrible work ethics, employees are allowed to just keep their terrible behavior going without punishment as management is unwilling to take the time and effort needed to go through the paperwork. This causes good employees to get burnt out and leave, which leads to a condensing of bad employees over time.

Nobody wants to change. Building on how hard it is to get reprimanded here or fired, everyone just wants to cruise to their OPERS retirement and do the minimum. If you are someone who wants to see the best possible of your work environment and coworkers, you won't see it here.

cons:
Everyone in a position of management has a god complex despite having to wait weeks and monthes for decisions from Columbus to do everything. 
There's no incentive to do good work, noone cares or notices. Pay is terrible and the benefits that they tout as incentive are crap to begin with and are being widdled away in the name of the pandemic.

5 years in and I was netting 29K annually (Grossing 40K with insurance that covered nothing and cost $500 a month, And contributing to OPERS at $5,000 a year when it will be solvent by 2030). A Crew of 10 was washed out to a crew of 5, I was the 2nd longest tenured employee on the crew when I left in Dec '21.

Morale was always AWFUL to begin with. I know everyone hates their job but we LITERALLY all said we hated waking up in the morning to come here. Its especially bad now amidst the ridiculous Covid protocols that they lie about then changed the rules a week later when they found out how many employees weren't buying into their vaccine threats. 
If you like extreme left leaning policies, you're going to LOVEEE working here!

Regardless of your plan, you will contribute 10% of your salary to a retirement plan. With the ARP, the university kicks in another ~11% to your retirement plan, and after a year everything is fully vested.
cons:
The transition to Workday has been an absolute mess, so the bureaucracy seems even worse than you would expect.

Working from home appears to be going away for a lot of people "just because."

You have to pay for parking, and it isn't cheap.

review_title: 1% pay raises makes employment at OSU unsustainable
job_title: Research Associate 1-Biological/Health Science in Columbus, OH
pros: Pros: retirement pension via OPERS (however, if you paid into Social Security and work for OSU for a long time you will lose more than 50% of your earned SS benefits due to the Windfall Elimination Provision); accrued vacation/sick time; 11 paid holidays annually; flexible work schedules/excellent work/life balance; friendly work environment; affordable health insurance, however, you are stuck with OSU Wexner Medical Center (unless you pay more for out-of-network) which is a teaching hospital that equates to longer treatment times due to the parade of medical students that are included in the patients’ treatment.
cons: Cons: pay raises (average 1%) don’t coincide with cost-of-living increases, especially since the pandemic (raises were “paused” last year, reinstated up to 2% this year at your manager’s discretion); parking is very expensive and not at all equitable - over $1K annually for main campus unless you enter the lottery for a pass downgrade, then it’s still around $500/yr, parking should be based on salary and not a flat rate for everyone; not enough parking on main campus which gets reduced every year, and parking on West Campus will add almost 45 minutes to your work day b/c of the shuttle commute time; new hires starting pay is close to/over what long term employees make (hence OSU ‘s HR dept’s lack of transparency regarding pay grades/salary); the bureaucracy is maddening - it takes the involvement of too many (often incompetent) people to get something simple done.

job_title: Coordinator, International Students in Columbus, OH
pros:
-Competitive salaries
-Amazing benefits and perks 
-Many opportunities to network or engage in personal development within the university
cons: There's definitely a very rigid hierarchy within the university. I would best describe the culture at THE Ohio State University as risk adverse, unimaginative, slow moving, cultish and bureaucratic. Working here makes me feel like I'm in a cult. You can't question anything or "rock the boat" under any circumstances. There's people who have been working here for 10, 20, and even 30+ years. They don't like change and they don't like risk. If you're OK with that, it's not so bad here. If you prefer more of a startup culture or a flatter organization, then you will hate it here. This is the kind of workplace where people go to retire. They do the minimum and then coast until they've reached retirement age.

job_title: Graduate Program Coordinator in Columbus, OH
pros:
Collaborative 
Daily work 
Most faculty & staff are great!
great insurance coverage & education benefits
cons:
Workday!
CAMPUSPARC
Poor communication from HR regarding training when changing systems for processing, sometimes micro-managers
poor staff retention efforts from HR--middle management

pros: Retirement benefits are good with no vesting requirements, a lot of professional development and opportunities to be involved (if your workload isn't too insane), you get a ton of sick time (not so much vacation though) if you're lazy, you probably won't get fired, good job security. Campus is beautiful.
cons:
Parking - I have to pay over $1,000 per year, and OSU refuses to pay for it. Salary is terrible. I'm required to have a Masters degree, which is the case for most entry-level positions in Student Life. It takes forever to move up, so when someone does get a higher level position, they never leave. Which means it is hard for others to move up. So much of your experience in dependent on the department you work in. Student Life is completely dysfunctional - 7 people from my area got fired for negligence. There were multiple scandals that hit the news as well. They have a lot of people in leadership who have no idea what they are doing, and no idea what the people below them are doing. There is a major hiring bias that favors minorities - I have been on search committees where we were literally told "you have to pick a black person." Tokenizing to the max. Residence Life is probably the worst unit in all of Student Life - such incompetent staff and top-heavy...horrific working with them.

The University just gave grad students major increases to stipends, so now they make more than many of their full-time supervisors. The University keeps chipping way at benefits - they cut the tuition benefit during the pandemic that is mostly utilized by the same people putting themselves at risk to keep the university open during the pandemic, and after people had already registered for classes...there was so much outrage that they reversed it. But if you're thinking of taking a job due to the tuition benefit...be aware they will probably cut it again.

There are no perks. I had to pay a monthly fee if I wanted to drink out of the water cooler. I also was asked to pay money to attend the staff holiday party. I'm so tired of being paid poorly and getting nickeled and dimed. I have interacted with the new President multiple times, and she clearly does not care about staff. It's all about the faculty. Even when pressed, she has nothing to say about the staff. HR is horrific - do not trust any of them. They have a strangle-hold on everything. Awhile back they did some new HR transformation that was supposed to increase efficiency and streamlining. Not a single HR downsize happened - they all walked away with higher titles and huge pay increases. These are the same people who are screwing over their own units during the University-wide Career Roadmap. They act like this will be some big pay equity thing for staff, when in reality all it is, is an excuse for them to downgrade staff and their "inflated job titles" which is actually a direct quote from a University Senate Finance report. Sure, they may bump some people up in pay, but they are then going to make the same amount of money as someone who just came into the University. Years of service, education, etc. aren't being taken into account in Career Roadmap, which is insulting. And the rest of us will be told we make too much (LOL) and will lose our ability to get pittance equity increases to our base pay. 

If your unit is not flush with cash, you'll never get a better job. I've been told by numerous supervisors they wish they could promote me, but they don't have the money. And I never get any higher up positions in other units, because they always hire their own people. They are so bad with internal candidates here it isn't funny. Many of the jobs posted are already intended for someone, but they don't have the decency to mention that on the job posting. If you want to move up, you have to move out.
